mn17:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn17:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the bhikkhus,
mn17:2.1: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you an exposition about jungle thickets.
mn17:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn17:3.1: “Bhikkhus, take the case of a bhikkhu who lives in a certain jungle thicket.
mn17:3.2: As he does so, his recollection does not become established, his mind does not become composed, his unexhausted defilements do not become exhausted, and he does not reach the unreached supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:3.3: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.
mn17:3.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection does not become established, my mind does not become composed, my unexhausted defilements do not become exhausted, and I do not reach the unreached supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:3.6: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.’
mn17:3.7: That bhikkhu should leave that jungle thicket that very time of night or day; he should not stay there.
mn17:4.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives in a certain jungle thicket.
mn17:4.2: His recollection does not become established …
mn17:4.3: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.
mn17:4.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection does not become established …
mn17:4.6: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.
mn17:4.7: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.
mn17:4.8: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection does not become established …’
mn17:4.9: That bhikkhu should, after appraisal, leave that jungle thicket; he should not stay there.
mn17:5.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives in a certain jungle thicket.
mn17:5.2: As he does so, his recollection becomes established, his mind becomes composed, his unexhausted defilements become exhausted, and he reaches the unreached supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:5.3: But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by. That bhikkhu should reflect:
mn17:5.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection becomes established …
mn17:5.6: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.
mn17:5.7: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.
mn17:5.8: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection becomes established …’
mn17:5.9: That bhikkhu should, after appraisal, stay in that jungle thicket; he should not leave.
mn17:6.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives in a certain jungle thicket.
mn17:6.3: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.
mn17:6.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my recollection becomes established …
mn17:6.6: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’
mn17:6.7: That bhikkhu should stay in that jungle thicket even for the rest of his life; he should not leave.
mn17:7-10.1: Take the case of a bhikkhu who lives in dependence on a village …
mn17:23.2: As he does so, his recollection does not become established, his mind does not become composed, his unexhausted defilements do not become exhausted, and he does not reach the unreached supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:23.3: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.
mn17:23.5: ‘… my recollection does not become established …
mn17:23.6: And the necessities of life are hard to come by.’
mn17:23.7: That bhikkhu should leave that person at any time of the day or night, without taking leave; he should not follow him. …
mn17:24.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives supported by an individual.
mn17:24.2: His recollection does not become established …
mn17:24.3: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.
mn17:24.5: ‘… my recollection does not become established …
mn17:24.6: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.’ …
mn17:24.9: That bhikkhu should, after appraisal, leave that person having taken leave; he should not follow him. …
mn17:25.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives supported by an individual.
mn17:25.3: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.
mn17:25.6: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.’ …
mn17:25.9: That bhikkhu should, after appraisal, follow that person; he should not leave.
mn17:26.1: Take another case of a bhikkhu who lives supported by an individual.
mn17:26.2: As he does so, his recollection becomes established, his mind becomes composed, his unexhausted defilements become exhausted, and he reaches the unreached supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:26.3: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.
mn17:26.5: ‘While living supported by this person, my recollection becomes established …
mn17:26.6: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’
mn17:26.7: That bhikkhu should follow that person even for the rest of his life; he should not leave him, even if dismissed.”
mn17:26.8: That is what the Buddha said.
mn17:26.9: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what the Buddha said.
